content:
Fulgencio Batista was a Cuban military leader and politician who served as the President of Cuba twice, first from 1940 to 1944 and later from 1952 to 1959. He first came to power in a military coup in 1933 and served as the President of Cuba from 1940-1944. After his term he went into exile and returned to Cuba in 1952 after winning the presidential election, however his second term was seen as a dictatorship by many.

During his second term, Batista's regime was marked by widespread corruption, human rights abuses, and suppression of political dissent. He was heavily criticized for his authoritarian rule, and many people in Cuba were unhappy with his government. Batista's regime was known for its close ties to the United States, and the country's economy was heavily dependent on American investment and tourism.

One of the most controversial aspects of Batista's regime was its close relationship with organized crime, particularly with American gangsters such as Meyer Lansky, who controlled much of the gambling and prostitution in Cuba. Batista was also heavily criticized for the way he handled the Cuban Revolution led by Fidel Castro and his followers which eventually led to his downfall.

On January 1, 1959, Batista and his government fled Cuba and the revolutionary forces led by Fidel Castro took over the country. Batista went into exile in the Dominican Republic, Spain and later Portugal where he died in 1973.
